content:
=== Game Rules ===
This is vgdl rule file:
BasicGame square_size=32
    SpriteSet
        background > Immovable img=oryx/space1 hidden=True
        base    > Immovable    color=WHITE img=oryx/planet
        avatar  > FlakAvatar   stype=sam img=oryx/spaceship1
        missile > Missile
            sam  > orientation=UP    color=BLUE singleton=True img=oryx/bullet1
            bomb > orientation=DOWN  color=RED  speed=0.5 img=oryx/bullet2
        alien   > Bomber       stype=bomb   prob=0.01  cooldown=3 speed=0.8
            alienGreen > img=oryx/alien3
            alienBlue > img=oryx/alien1
        portal  > invisible=True hidden=True
        	portalSlow  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienBlue  cooldown=16   total=20 img=portal
        	portalFast  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienGreen  cooldown=12   total=20 img=portal

    LevelMapping
        . > background
        0 > background base
        1 > background portalSlow
        2 > background portalFast
        A > background avatar

    TerminationSet
        SpriteCounter      stype=avatar               limit=0 win=False
        MultiSpriteCounter stype1=portal stype2=alien limit=0 win=True

    InteractionSet
        avatar  EOS  > stepBack
        alien   EOS  > turnAround
        missile EOS  > killSprite

        base bomb > killBoth
        base sam > killBoth scoreChange=1

        base   alien > killSprite
        avatar alien > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        avatar bomb  > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        alien  sam   > killSprite scoreChange=2

This is vgdl rule in natural language:
Overview:
• Genre & Theme: This is an arcade-style, space shooter game reminiscent of classic space invaders. You control a spaceship (the avatar) against waves of alien enemies emerging from mysterious portals.

Key Mechanics:
• Player Character: You control a spaceship (the avatar), which fires blue “sam” projectiles upward. The game uses a “FlakAvatar” mechanism that likely gives you some maneuverability and shooting ability.
• Enemy Behavior: Aliens (and their two variants, represented by different colored sprites) are spawned via portals. They act as bombers—dropping red “bomb” projectiles downward toward your base.
• Projectile Dynamics: Your ship fires “sam” bullets against incoming aliens, and there is a missile sprite that interacts with the edge of the screen by disappearing (“killSprite”). This suggests both your shots and enemy bombs have finite lifespans or travel distances.
• Environmental Elements: The “base” (shown as a planet) is immovable and appears to be a protective or strategic asset. The background and level layout provide obstacles or structure that influence movement and positioning. The grid layout shows placements of obstacles (zeros) and open space dots, as well as the location of the avatar (denoted by “A”).

Objectives & Win/Loss Conditions:
• Primary Objective: Clear the level by eliminating all enemy aliens and stopping further enemy spawn points (portals). The win condition is reached when there are no remaining aliens or active portals.
• Loss Condition: The game ends in a loss if your avatar is destroyed (i.e., when there are no more avatar sprites left).

Interaction Details:
• Different collision effects are set up:
 – When your bullet (“sam”) hits an alien, the alien is killed and you gain score (with a bonus if hit by “sam” on an alien).
 – If aliens or bombs collide with your avatar, you lose points and risk destruction.
 – The base plays an interesting role: collisions between the base and an enemy bomb lead to both being destroyed, while collisions with “sam” can grant a small score increase.
• Movement behaviors like “stepBack” for the avatar at the edge of the screen and “turnAround” for aliens on EOS (edge-of-screen) keep the action contained.

Overall Strategy:
• Stay Mobile and Accurate: As the pilot, maneuver your avatar to keep out of the path of enemy bombs and aliens, while carefully aiming your “sam” shots. Avoid unnecessary collisions, as these reduce your score and may cost you the game.
• Target Prioritization: Focus on eliminating aliens quickly—especially those spawned steadily from portals—to prevent them from building up and overwhelming your defenses. Since your score benefits more from directly taking aliens out with “sam” (scoreChange=+2) compared to other interactions, precision attacks are encouraged.
• Protect the Base: Although your avatar is your primary asset, the base acts as an immovable defensive object. Try to prevent enemy bombs from hitting the base by intercepting them early. Keeping the base intact might help manage enemy collisions, as some interactions (like base alien) automatically kill the alien.
• Positioning and Anticipation: Understand that alien bombs come from above (orientation DOWN) and your bullets travel upward (orientation UP). Use this vertical dynamic to time your shots and dodges. Also, keep an eye on the moving enemies—they reverse direction on hitting the edges, so anticipating their path helps in lining up shots.
• Manage Portal Spawns: Since the portals spawn aliens at specific cooldowns and quantities, plan to clear these sources early. Eliminating the portal sprites will gradually reduce the enemy wave pressure and eventually trigger the win condition.

Conclusion:
This space shooter demands accuracy, quick reflexes, and smart prioritization. Stay on the move, target aliens before their numbers grow, and balance offense with defense to protect your base. Follow the movement cues and collision effects to maximize your score and secure victory by completely clearing the enemy forces and portals.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.

Action: 3

I'm moving right to slightly reposition away from the direct drop zone of the bomb cluster while keeping close enough for coordinated sam support, expecting this will reduce imminent collision risk and better align upcoming shots against the bomb threats.

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
background -> '.'
background base -> '0'
background portalSlow -> '1'
background portalFast -> '2'
alienBlue -> '@'
base -> '#'
sam -> '$'
alienBlue bomb -> '%'
bomb -> '&'
bomb sam -> '*'
